title: Pyrrhus of Epirus
summary: Pyrrhus (/ˈpɪrəs/; Greek: Πύρρος Pýrrhos; 319/318–272 BC) was a Greek king and statesman of the Hellenistic period.[1][2][3][4][5] He was king of the Greek tribe of Molossians,[4][6] of the royal Aeacid house,[7] and later he became king (Malalas also called him toparch[8]) of Epirus. He was one of the strongest opponents of early Rome, and regarded as one of the greatest generals of antiquity.[9] Several of his victorious battles caused him unacceptably heavy losses, from which the term "Pyrrhic victory" was coined.
